summary: This document is an email chain from August 2020 discussing the logistics of transferring digital evidence (hard drives and thumb drives containing device extractions with NYC evidence numbers) related to the Epstein case for upload to the Relativity review platform. The correspondence involves coordination between legal/technical teams regarding the status of evidence processing, confirmation of received materials, and identification of outstanding items requiring hardware recovery.

persons.name: Francesco
persons.context: Mentioned as a potential point of contact for assistance with outstanding evidence issues when the primary contact is unavailable.

events.title: Hard Drive Shipment Confirmation
events.description: Confirmation that a hard drive containing evidence materials was sent and is expected to arrive the next day.

events.title: Thumb Drive Shipment Planned
events.description: Plan to mail a thumb drive containing folders for five specific evidence devices (NYCO24332, NYCO24369, etc.) for processing and upload to Relativity.

events.title: Evidence Status Review and Questions
events.description: Ongoing review of evidence spreadsheets, identification of missing items (e.g., NYC027913), questions about duplicate folders, and confirmation of zero-byte files in initial device extractions.

keyFacts: The email chain details the active transfer and processing of digital evidence from numerous devices (referenced by NYC evidence numbers like NYCO24332, NYC027913) in the Epstein investigation as of August 2020.

Evidence processing involved challenges such as duplicate folders, missing items, and approximately 71,000 zero-byte (empty) files recovered from initial device extractions, which was noted as not unusual for forensic software.

Some evidence items, specifically two servers with multiple drives, were noted as physically failed and required specialized hardware recovery at an HQ facility, indicating a complex and lengthy data recovery process.

The correspondence is focused on administrative coordination for uploading evidence to 'Relativity,' a document review platform commonly used in legal proceedings, highlighting the procedural phase of evidence handling post-seizure.
